summary: None

headline: The Nation's Unemployed
summary: Unemployment rates were little changed in most states in November, as a recovery in the labor market remained sluggish across the country.

headline: Tokyo's Adult Manga Clampdown
summary: In Tokyo, city authorities have approved tighter regulations on the sale of manga comic books with explicit adult content.

headline: Rangers 4, Coyotes 3
summary: Erik Christensen pots the lone shootout goal to lift the Blueshirts.

headline: Nets 97, Wizards 89
summary: Devin Harris's 29 points led the Nets to a victory to snap an eight-game skid.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & amplifications for Dec. 17, 2010.

headline: Taxpayers in the Balance
summary: Comparing what a sampling of filers would owe under the pending tax legislation and what they would have paid if current tax rates and other temporary patches were allowed to expire.

headline: Isles 3, Ducks 2
summary: The Islanders scored three times in a 99-second span to win for just the second time in 22 games.

headline: Treasury to Sell $57 Billion in Securities
summary: The Treasury plans to sell $57 billion in short-term bills on Monday.

headline: He Spurned New York, He Burned New York
summary: LeBron Drops a Triple Double on the Knicks to Lead the Heat to a Win at the Garden

headline: A Klingon Christmas Carol
summary: Across the country this week, productions of Charles Dickens's 'A Christmas Carol' are warming hearts. In Chicago, one version poses this question: What if Charles Dickens were a Trekkie?

headline: Christie Picks Texan to Promote Garden State
summary: Tracye McDaniel, who worked in Houston and for the state of Texas in economic development and tourism roles, will be CEO of Choose New Jersey, an organization assigned to promote New Jersey to businesses.

headline: Date Set for Restaurant, Hotel Wage Rules
summary: New York state's restaurant and hotel operators will have until Feb. 28 to make necessary payroll-system changes to accommodate a new wage order.

headline: Orbital Proposes Commercial Spaceplane
summary: Orbital Sciences entered the race to provide commercial transportation for U.S. astronauts, proposing a spaceplane resembling a slimmed-down remake of the retiring space shuttle.

headline: Hangover Brunch
summary: Partygoers can now find the "Hangover Cure," a spicy dish that jolts the senses, on the brunch menu at Mexican-American restaurant MexiQ in Astoria, Queens.

headline: Roubini: Rash Policy Is Jeopardizing Growth
summary: Low growth and low inflation in the U.S. and Europe is being exacerbated by rashly implemented fiscal austerity that will stifle growth and eventually lead to debt restructuring, economist Nouriel Roubini said.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 18-19
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 18-19

headline: Venezuela To Call Banks Public Utilities
summary: Venezuelan lawmakers capped a busy week approving special powers for President Hugo Chavez along with a bill that categorizes banks as public utilities, a move critics says will make it easier to take over financial institutions.

headline: Transocean Ordered to Turn Over Records
summary: A federal judge in New Orleans has ordered Transocean to turn over safety records related to the other rigs it had in the Gulf of Mexico in April when its Deepwater Horizon rig exploded.

headline: Drug Stocks Fall, Tech Rises
summary: The Dow industrials fell as big drug makers' shares came under pressure amid fears of tighter regulation, but tech shares rose on better-than-expected earnings reports.

headline: Rising Car Sales Fuel Auto ABS Market
summary: Improved sales of vehicles means banks have a greater volume of loans to package into auto-loan-backed securities for sale to investors, which translates into better rates to borrowers.

headline: Shallow Bathtub Is Deep Disappointment
summary: With the gut renovation of her Harlem brownstone nearly complete, Julia gets tripped up in her hunt for bathroom fixtures.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, a soldier comes home to Vermont, a darts champion competes, Santa does some checking up on one boy, and more.

headline: Rep. Frank to Fed: Tread Cautiously on Debit-Card Fees
summary: House Financial Services Committee Chairman Barney Frank is asking the head of the Federal Reserve to make sure that community banks, credit unions and consumers aren't hurt by proposed rules limiting the debit-card fees banks charge merchants.

headline: Oil Prices Settle at $88
summary: Crude-oil futures finished higher, as signs of economic improvement helped boost the case for pricier oil.

headline: Gold Prices Push Higher
summary: Gold futures rose as worries about Irish debt mounted. The December Comex contract added 0.6% to settle at $1,378.60 a troy ounce.

headline: Brazil Joblessness Hits Record Low
summary: Brazil's unemployment rate fell below 6% for the first time on record, underscoring the strong recovery of the Brazilian economy from the global crisis but adding to the central bank's concerns about rising inflation.

headline: Making Progress
summary: Brownstone Diary columnist Julia Angwin nears the finish line on the gut renovation of her Harlem apartment. See photos.

headline: Suburb vs. Exurb
summary: A house hunter in New Jersey asks, Is it better to buy a home in a close-in suburb or a newer house farther away from the city?

headline: Funding Boosts for SEC, CFTC in Doubt
summary: Funding boosts for U.S. federal securities and futures regulators working to implement the new Dodd-Frank financial law are now in doubt after a Senate spending measure collapsed.

headline: The Sunburst Mirror
summary: Precious antique or affordable accessory, the decorative motif adds sparkle to any space.

headline: The New Wave
summary: Oahu, that diamond-shaped speck in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, may not be Hawaii's biggest island, but it's certainly the one to explore.

headline: Europe's Banks Lead Market Declines
summary: Banking stocks fell, pushing European benchmarks into the red Friday, on disappointment over the European Union's response to the debt crisis and a downgrade of Ireland's credit rating.

headline: Schiff Nutrition International, First South Bancorp: Biggest Price Decliners (WNI, FSBK)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Lehman Real-Estate Settlements Approved
summary: Lehman Brothers won bankruptcy-court approval to settle two real-estate disputes under deals that will bring the failed investment bank more than $150 million and will save it another $12 million.

headline: U.K. Immigration Cap Ruled Unlawful
summary: The U.K.'s High Court has ruled that the coalition government's temporary cap on non-European Union immigrants is unlawful.

headline: SEC's Cohen to Take Enforcement Post
summary: One of SEC Chairman Mary Schapiro's top advisers, Stephen L. Cohen, will move to a senior post in the SEC's enforcement unit.

headline: Baxter Dialysis Issue Affects Europe, Not U.S.
summary: The potential presence of harmful substances in Baxter International's dialysis solutions for patients with kidney failure affects Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Argentina, but not the U.S. or other markets.

headline: Poland Rejects Russian Findings in Air Crash
summary: Poland's prime minister rejected the findings of Russian investigators looking into the April plane crash that killed the Polish president, a development that threatens to set back warming ties between the two countries.

headline: Amazon Adds Rubinstein to Board
summary: Jon Rubinstein, the former Palm CEO and current H-P executive, has been named to the board of directors at Amazon.com.

headline: The Pioneering SUV Isn't One Anymore
summary: The Ford Explorer, which popularized the truck-based, fuel-hogging sport utility, is transformed into a crossover, says the Journal's Dan Neil.

headline: Former Blackwater Bought by Investment Group
summary: An investment group with ties to the founder of the company formerly known as Blackwater has bought the security firm.

headline: South Korea Halts Woori Finance Sale
summary: The South Korean government halted the sale of its $5.8 billion controlling stake in Woori Finance, citing adverse market conditions and regulatory hurdles that undercut the privatization effort.

headline: IRS Issues 2011 Tax Tables
summary: The Internal Revenue Service on Friday issued income-tax withholding tables for 2011, one day after Congress passed a measure to keep current tax rates in place for the next two years.

headline: Pfizer to Pay New CEO $1.7 Million Base Salary
summary: Pfizer will pay its new chief executive, Ian Read, a base salary of $1.7 million plus a bonus for 2011.

headline: Luxury Stocks Flying High
summary: From Cartier to LVMH, luxury retailers are having themselves a merry little Christmas. Sales are surging here and abroad. Profits are widening. And stocks are surging, writes Brett Arends.

headline: IMF: Irish Budget Cuts Aren't Enough
summary: The Irish government won't achieve its goal of cutting its budget deficit to 3% of gross domestic product by 2015 unless it makes further spending cuts or finds new ways to increase its tax revenues, the IMF said.

headline: We Woof You a Merry Christmas
summary: Dogs and cats are joining in the annual ritual of sending season's greetings. Card makers are rolling out designs that enable people to send cards from their pets to commemorate nearly every occasion that humans do.

headline: Cephalon's CEO Dies While on Medical Leave
summary: Cephalon said Frank Baldino Jr., its founder and chief executive, died Thursday evening, following months on medical leave for an undisclosed illness.

headline: Wells Fargo To Forgive Loans In Student Death, Disability
summary: Previously, a student borrower's co-signer -- often a family member -- was required to continue repaying the loan, even if the student died or became incapacitated.

headline: FSA Toughens U.K. Pay Guidelines
summary: The U.K. Financial Services Authority issued compensation guidelines for the financial-services industry that are broadly in line with rules set by an EU-wide committee.

headline: Billionaire's Beachfront Estate
summary: Conair and Cuisinart owner Leandro Rizzuto has listed a beachfront property in Greenwich, Conn., that has Italian marble throughout for nearly $19 million.

headline: InterMune Boosted by European Regulatory Opinion
summary: InterMune said a panel from the European medicines regulator gave a positive opinion on its application to market its treatment for the fatal condition known as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

headline: Nations Team Up to Curb EU Budget
summary: The U.K., Germany, and France are joining forces to limit future increases in the European Union's annual budget, including a plan for a virtual freeze between 2014 and 2020.

headline: EU Pledges 'Adequate' Fund Support
summary: European leaders agreed to ensure "adequate financial support" in the euro zone's €440 billion bailout fund, although there are no immediate plans to increase its size.

headline: U.K. Banks Face More Bad-Debt Charges
summary: U.K. banks face further but "manageable" bad-debt write-downs over the coming years if the country's economy deteriorates and interest rates rise, the Bank of England said.

headline: Moody's Downgrades Ireland's Debt
summary: Moody's downgraded Ireland's debt to Baa1 from Aa2, warning the government's financial strength could deteriorate if growth falls short of government projections.

headline: Hochtief Holds Firm Against ACS Bid
summary: Hochtief recommended that shareholders reject the latest offer from the Spanish builder Actividades de Construccion y Servicios.

headline: Facebook Apologizes for Outage
summary: Facebook shut down its site for a brief period Thursday after some internal prototypes were leaked.

headline: U.S. Sharpens Criticism of Afghan Graft
summary: Top U.S. officials in Kabul said any military gains made by coalition forces will be reversed unless the Afghan government cracks down on corruption.

headline: Facebook as Travel Guidebook?
summary: The guy who sat behind you in high school knows the perfect hotel in Hamburg.

headline: Many Winners, a Few Losers
summary: The passage by the House of a bipartisan tax bill resolves many urgent questions weighing on individuals and businesses—but also creates groups of winners and losers.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash, 50 Years Later
summary: A 1960 plane crash in Brooklyn's Park Slope neighborhood claimed 134 lives. Here's a look back at the crash and the new memorial erected to commemorate the victims at Greenwood Cemetery.

headline: Macau Rejects SJM Land Request
summary: The Macau government has rejected SJM Holdings' application for the same land Sands China was denied earlier this month, leaving a key piece of land up for grabs in the world's largest gambling market.

headline: BOE: Debt Woes Need 'Comprehensive' Solution
summary: The Bank of England called for a "comprehensive" solution for sovereign-debt woes to reassure investors and avoid contagion from spreading.

headline: PBOC: Interest Rates to Gradually Liberalize
summary: People's Bank of China Gov. Zhou Xiaochuan said Friday that China will gradually make interest rates more market-determined and that interest rate liberalization can improve the allocation of resources.

headline: Yahoo Plans to Shut AltaVista, Other Sites
summary: Yahoo said it is planning to shut down several underperforming properties, including its AltaVista search engine and Delicious bookmarking service, as it continues a years-long turnaround effort.

headline: Uniqlo Plans Expanded Presence in China
summary: Fast Retailing aims to introduce its Uniqlo stores in the growing Indian and Brazilian markets within five years, and to vastly expand in China, where the number of stores will surpass that of Japan by 2020.

headline: Turkey Increases Reserve Ratio
summary: Turkey's central bank lifted its reserve requirements, a day after cutting interest rates, in a one-two punch designed to stop the economy from overheating and to curb speculative investment inflows.

headline: German Ifo Survey Hits Fresh High
summary: The euro zone's fiscal crisis hasn't dented German business confidence, the Ifo measure of sentiment showed, as it hit a fresh record high in December.

headline: Photos: Day Two, Third Ashes Test Match
summary: A dramatic second day of the third Ashes test saw Australia come back strong, thanks to the bowling of Mitchell Johnson, who snared 6-38. At the end of the second day, the match is tipped in favor of Australia who were 119-3 in their second innings at stumps.

headline: ECB's Weber Rejects Common Bonds
summary: The joint issuance of bonds by euro-zone member states is no solution for the region's sovereign-debt problems, said Axel Weber, the president of the Deutsche Bundesbank and member of the ECB's governing council.

headline: Euro-Zone Trade Surplus Widens
summary: The euro zone's balance in trade of goods with the rest of the world remained in surplus in October, and was double the level reported in September.

headline: Korea Gas Endorses Massive Australian Project
summary: Easing doubts about Asian buyers' appetite for a promising but nascent source of natural gas, Korea Gas Corp. took a 15% stake in a $15.8 billion Australian gas export venture.

headline: Australia to Probe Migrant Boat Deaths
summary: Australian officials will launch a criminal investigation into the deaths of least 28 asylum seekers whose boat smashed apart off the coast of Australia's Christmas Island.

headline: Zoomlion Prices Hong Kong IPO at Lower End
summary: Machinery maker Changsha Zoomlion Heavy Industry Science & Technology Development Co. raised $1.68 billion ahead of its Hong Kong initial public offering after pricing its shares toward the bottom of the indicative range.

headline: Asia Mixed; Taiwan Hits 31-Month High
summary: Asian stock markets were mixed, with Taiwan's market rising to a 31-month high while China remained sluggish on concerns over further tightening measures. Shanghai was off 0.2%.

headline: Asiana May Sell Korea Express Stake
summary: Asiana Airlines, South Korea's No. 2 airline by revenue, is considering selling a 23.95% stake in Korea Express to secure capital for the restructuring of its cash-strapped parent, Kumho Asiana Group.

headline: Singapore Exports Slow
summary: Growth in Singapore's key non-oil exports slowed sharply in November after shipments to the city-state's most important markets declined, but analysts said the moderation was expected and points to a more sustainable pace of growth next year.

headline: California Adopts Cap And Trade
summary: California regulators adopted the first large-scale cap-and-trade program in the U.S., in a move officials say will protect the environment without hurting the state's still-struggling economy.

headline: Japanese Police Investigate Bus Stabbing
summary: An unemployed Japanese man with a knife attacked students and other passengers waiting on two public buses outside a train station Friday in a rampage that left 13 people injured, police said.

headline: Queens Man Sentenced in Shooting Spree
summary: Matthew Coletta was sentenced by Judge Michael Aloise in Queens Supreme Court three weeks after being found guilty of murder and 13 counts of attempted murder along with assault and weapon charges.

headline: Payroll Chief Is Suspended
summary: Mayor Michael Bloomberg said he was suspending Joel Bondy, the head of the payroll-administration office Thursday, one day after federal prosecutors charged consultants with defrauding the city out of more than $80 million that were tied to the updating of its timekeeping system.

headline: Boyfriend Indicted in Designer's Death
summary: A grand jury indicted Nicholas Brooks, the son of an Oscar-winning songwriter, in connection with the death of his girlfriend, fashion designer Sylvie Cachay, who was found lifeless in an overflowing bathtub at exclusive Manhattan hotel-spa last week.

headline: None of Bodies Found Are of Missing Woman
summary: Police said tests show that none of the four female bodies found dumped along a stretch of beaches in Long Island are those of a New Jersey prostitute whose disappearance seven months touched off the search earlier this week that led to the grisly discovery.

headline: Uranium Investors Enriched by China
summary: Great expectations for China's nuclear power program cause the price of uranium to soar to $65 a pound. And market watchers don't expect the price to fall anytime soon.

headline: Wall Street Titans Rally at Yearly Fund-Raiser
summary: Like much of Wall Street, UJA-Federation of New York's annual Wall Street fund-raising dinner has rebounded. Wednesday night, the group raised $19.5 million—up $1.5 million from 2008.

headline: H-P Says U.S. Bribery Probe Has Expanded
summary: A bribery investigation that originally focused on a Hewlett-Packard contract in Russia has expanded to sales in several European countries.

headline: New Rules Mean More Capital for Banks
summary: The Bank for International Settlements said banks would have faced a capital shortfall of about $763 billion if the new global regulatory standards known as Basel III had taken effect last year.

headline: Spending Bill Withdrawn in Senate
summary: In a victory for fiscal conservatives, Senate Democrats abandoned a $1.1 trillion bill to fund the federal government for the remaining nine and a half months of the fiscal year, acknowledging that there isn't sufficient support among lawmakers.

headline: Seduced by Subtitles
summary: Tino Balio's "The Foreign Film Renaissance on American Screens, 1946-1973," tells the story of America's postwar fascination with Bergman, Kurosawa, Italian Neo-Realism—and Brigitte Bardot. Richard Schickel reviews.

headline: Condominiums in Hotel Resorts
summary: Luxury condominiums in Park City, Utah, Sarasota, Florida, and Coronado California.

headline: Euro Edges Up Against Dollar
summary: The euro rose marginally against the dollar, as traders awaited details from a European Union summit that might indicate a permanent solution to the euro zone's debt crisis is at hand.

headline: P&G Stays Firm on Sales Outlook
summary: Consumer-products company Procter & Gamble reaffirmed its sales and profit forecasts for the current quarter and fiscal year.

headline: Nasdaq Buyback Spurs Options Buying
summary: Shares of Nasdaq OMX Group zoomed after it launched a major buyback, and options traders seem optimistic the climb could continue.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Richard Epstein on Virginia v. Sebelius, which declared unconstitutional the individual mandate in ObamaCare.

headline: Warm Tunes for Botti and Spirit
summary: Will Friedwald surveys jazz offerings in New York City: Chris Botti Quintet, Craig Harris and 'God's Trombones,' Ehud Asheri, and more.

headline: Kishan Manocha: An Open Letter to the Islamic Republic
summary: Tehran's persecution of its religious minorities violates its own constitution.

headline: Magnolia Cupcakes Readies Online Push
summary: Magnolia is expanding, again. It signed a 10-year lease this week for a 5,200-square-foot production facility  in Harlem that will serve as a distribution point when the baker begins peddling its goods on the Web.

headline: Widow to Return Funds in Madoff Case
summary: The estate of Jeffry Picower, a major investor in Bernard Madoff's Ponzi scheme, has agreed to repay $7.2 billion to victims of the fraud in a settlement, a major victory for Madoff's victims.

headline: Walking in a Winter Wonderland
summary: From gentle strolls around resorts to snow-encrusted log cabins for a chance to see the northern lights—a selection of the best winter walking in Europe.

headline: Carney and Jolis: Toward a United States of Europe
summary: French Finance Minister Christine Lagarde tells the Journal it will take much stronger fiscal and economic coordination among EU member states for the euro to work.

headline: Starving Artists Get Assistance
summary: A dance-company founder is launching a contemporary dance festival to teach artists how to raise funds.

headline: LeBron James, Meet NYC
summary: It's unclear what kind of reaction LeBron James will get at Madison Square Garden. But we do have some indication of what New Yorkers think of him.

headline: City Studies a New Science School
summary: The city is seeking academic institutions to build a top-tier applied-science facility in New York, city officials announced at Google's Chelsea office.

headline: Margot Cohen: How Indonesia Gets Its Groove On
summary: A new book on an Indonesian song-and-dance art shimmers with reflections of the country's identity, politics and history.

headline: U.S. Seeks Web 'Bill of Rights'
summary: The Obama administration said Americans should have a "privacy bill of rights" to help regulate the commercial collection of consumer data online.

headline: Business Watch
summary: Here is a selection of business news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Yuletide Pop's Golden Age
summary: Why have so few songwriters since the 1940s had any luck writing a hit Christmas song? Eric Felten discusses.

headline: Sprint Tackles Subscriber Losses
summary: Once a feeding ground for its bigger competitors, Sprint has largely stabilized its customer base and revenue. Satisfaction with the carrier, once known for abysmal customer service, now rivals Verizon Wireless.

headline: Giants Receivers Need Ph.D.s In Route-Running
summary: It's a tough offense to master, but it gives receivers the option to amend their routes to beat the defense.

headline: Breast Cancer and the FDA
summary: The agency's Avastin decision is a tragedy for desperately ill women.

headline: EU Has Concerns on Big Intel Deal
summary: European antitrust officials have expressed concerns during their preliminary review of Intel's $7.68 billion deal to buy security-software specialist McAfee.

headline: Packages Perk Up Shippers' Holiday
summary: Package shipper FedEx said fiscal second-quarter revenue rose and the company raised its earnings forecast for the year.

headline: Blackstone Reworks $7 Billion in Debt
summary: Blackstone reached an agreement to restructure about $7 billion of the remaining debt tied to its epic purchase of Sam Zell's Equity Office Properties Trust.

headline: No Grinch Yet for Economic Data
summary: Renewed optimism has also pushed Treasury yields and mortgage rates sharply higher. That could mean happy economic days are here again. Or it could mean another hit to housing.

headline: Swift Rise in Yields Pushes Up Mortgages
summary: The sudden jump in Treasury yields has driven 30-year mortgage rates above 5%, keeping pressure on the struggling housing market and countering the Fed's efforts to help the economy.

headline: U.K. Festive Retail Sales Rise
summary: U.K. retail sales in November rose roughly in line with expectations, providing further evidence of robust consumer spending ahead of the Christmas period and January's sales-tax increase.

headline: Red Card for Debit Fees
summary: The market's fast and furious reaction to the Fed's bombshell on Visa and MasterCard may prove too harsh.

headline: Spat Roils Top Party in Japan
summary: An intensifying conflict between leaders of the Democratic Party of Japan and the party's beleaguered power broker raises concerns that the DPJ may unravel.

headline: Myanmar's Links With Pyongyang Stir Nuclear Fears
summary: The United Nations' nuclear watchdog has written to Myanmar's military government in recent weeks asking to visit sites in the Southeast Asian country allegedly involved in clandestine nuclear activities, according to officials briefed on the correspondence.

headline: Dreaming of a Hong Kong Christmas
summary: With giant Santas and purple glitter, the city is giving mainland Chinese a taste of over-the-top yuletide décor.

headline: Closer Fiscal Union:  A Collective Guarantee
summary: Debt restructuring could be one part of the longer-term resolution of the crisis, together with a move toward deeper European integration to harness the region's collective strength.

headline: Reflecting on Priceless Perfection
summary: The treasures on display at the Nieuwe Kerk this winter are priceless, but the most striking element of the "Passion for Perfection" exhibition is an effective design element: the simple use of mirrors.

headline: Improving Pilot Visibility
summary: Honeywell International, seeking to allow jetliners to land in minimum visibility, is combining computer-generated images and enhanced infrared views of runways to create what it considers the cockpit of the future.

headline: $1,000,000,000,000  Worse Than a Trillion
summary: Eric Felten's review of Ralph Keyes's "Euphemania" (Bookshelf, Dec. 14) is interesting regarding what does or doesn't constitute a euphemism, and the virtues and vices of euphemisms. $1 Trillion is a euphemism for $1,000,000,000,000.

headline: Judge Leery of Health Mandate
summary: A federal judge in the 20-state lawsuit against the health overhaul signaled he's sympathetic to the plaintiffs' argument that requiring Americans to carry health insurance violates the Constitution.

headline: The Santa Claus of Christmas Songs
summary: Music insiders covet Eddie Gorodetsky's holiday mixes. Says he: "People will listen to anything if you put sleigh bells on it."

headline: Relishing Childhood Toys
summary: Vintage toy auctions appeal to nostalgic parents, while Forbes famed toy collection comes under the hammer on Dec.17 followed by Bonhams marathon doll and toy auction Dec. 21.

headline: Fashion, Façades and Found Objects
summary: Lisa Rossi reviews new books on design and architecture, including Massimo Listri's "New Asian Interiors" where, in a sprawling Bangkok home, a Burmese Buddha peers down from a pedestal on a high-tech bathtub.

headline: Time to Change the Guard for U.S. Space Exploration?
summary: Homer Hickam has a peculiarly mixed-up idea about the space exploration business "How About a Moon Base?" (op-ed, Dec. 14). He accurately describes the emptiness and lassitude at NASA and the vibrancy and life within private space ventures.

headline: Yankees Sign Martin to Be Starting Catcher
summary: The Yankees signed catcher Russell Martin to a one-year, $4 million contract. Mr. Martin, 27, will be the Yankees' primary catcher next season, enabling them to move Jorge Posada to designated hitter.

headline: Alan Blinder: Our Dickensian Economy
summary: Since 1978, productivity in the nonfarm business sector is up 86% but real compensation per hour is up just 37%. Is that fair?

headline: Minnesotans Tackle Shovel-Ready Project
summary: Hundreds have worked four-hour shoveling shifts to prepare for Monday's game between the Vikings and Chicago Bears. Plus, Saints tight end Jeremy Shockey will head to Scotland for the sixth annual Drambuie Pursuit.

headline: India Central Bank Acts on Cash Crunch
summary: India's central bank left its key policy interest rates unchanged, as widely expected, but moved to tackle a liquidity crunch by freeing up cash banks can lend and planning to buy more government bonds.

headline: Hong Kong to Allow Reverse Mortgages After Long Debate
summary: After years of debate, Hong Kong has decided to allow reverse mortgages, a way for elderly to tap the value of their homes in a way that has drawn criticism elsewhere.

headline: Alain Coumont Gets His Hands Dirty
summary: Alain Coumont, the founder of high-end bakery chain Le Pain Quotidien, lives and breathes organic food, spending his free time at his farm in France, growing parsley and sipping homemade wine.

headline: Why Investors Haven't Warmed to Natural Gas
summary: Low prices reflect concern that the U.S. is oversupplied, but some analysts see hope as natural-gas producers begin to scale back and electricity generators boost demand.

headline: Debt Restructuring:  A Hit for Bondholders
summary: A debt default by a euro member or two—also known as a restructuring when that is done after talking with creditors—requires much less fantasy to believe in, most observers agree.

headline: The Future of German Theater
summary: In the course of a few seasons, Berlin-based author and director Roland Schimmelpfennig has become German-speaking Europe's most celebrated younger playwright.

headline: The Whole Ski Kit and Kaboodle
summary: Most skiers should give a thought to their appearance on the slopes, where crimes of fashion are writ large.

headline: Cuisinart's Owner Tries to Avoid Blending In
summary: Conair and Cuisinart owner Leandro Rizzuto has listed a beachfront property in Greenwich, Conn., for nearly $19 million.
